title: 108_hr2022
content: The "Leave No Securities Behind Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes provisions for the registration of securities. The "Leave No Securities Behind Act" includes amendments to the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act regarding mortgage-backed securities and subordinate obligations issued by Fannie Mae. Securities and obligations issued under this subsection will not be exempt securities under the laws administered by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The "Leave No Securities Behind Act" amends the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act to specify that securities issued by Fannie Mae will not be exempt from laws administered by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The "Leave No Securities Behind Act" amends the Federal National Mortgage Association Charter Act to specify that transactions involving the initial disposition of pooled certificates by approved sellers shall be exempt from certain securities laws administered by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Approved sellers are institutions approved by the corporation to sell mortgage loans in exchange for pooled certificates. Approved sellers can exchange mortgage loans for pooled certificates, which are single class mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by the corporation. These securities can be issued directly to the approved seller in exchange for the underlying mortgage loans. Additionally, mortgage-backed securities issued by the corporation for cash are considered mortgage related securities under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended regarding Freddie Mac, stating that securities issued or guaranteed by the Corporation are not exempt securities under SEC laws. Transactions involving pooled certificates acquired from the Corporation by approved sellers are exempt from certain provisions of the Securities Act of 1933. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to clarify that securities issued or guaranteed by Freddie Mac are not exempt securities under SEC laws. Approved sellers can exchange mortgage loans for pooled certificates, which are single class mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by Freddie Mac. The Securities and Exchange Commission may issue regulations regarding these transactions. The Securities and Exchange Commission may issue regulations to implement the amendments made by this section. The amendments will take effect after a 180-day period from the enactment of the Act, applying to fiscal years of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac starting after this period. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON REGISTRATION FEES. Section 6(b)(2) of the Securities Act of 1933 is amended to limit the fees required for registration statements filed by applicants in a fiscal year to five percent of the target offsetting collection amount. This amendment excludes fees for registration statements related to business combinations. The amendment under subsection (a) of the Securities Act of 1933 will be effective after a 180-day period from the enactment of the Act.
